page.title: 16PEAT CUTTING
page.content: Thorne Waste, Rawcliff Moor, Goole Moor but is usually known in its entirety as Thorne Moors. Peat cutting has existed on this moor for at least 800yrs. Manorial grants of turbary on Thorne moors was mentioned in the late 12th century. By 1538 peat cutting was regarded as an ancient custom. Even after drainage of Hatfield Chase in 1626 peat cutting continued. The peat was cut and dried by being piled up on the spot. When it was dry it was put onto long narrow boats. These used to go along the deep natural drains and artificial channels which ended in the Rivers Ouse, Aire or Trent. By the 19th century the trade was in decline, the 30-40 boats operating in the 18th century had, by 1820, been reduced to 8 or 9.
